title: When will fatalities caused by the Wuhan coronavirus (2019-nCoV) exceed those from Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS), according to the World Health Organization (WHO)?
preds: Passed today. I am off the mark on this one.
And we'll definitely be somewhere past come the next WHO report ( https://twitter.com/BNODesk/status/1226270394174386178 ).

I never thought the Xi administration has come down to such low levels of indecency and incompetence.
I was expecting a substantially better response considering the economic situation of the country and their global image deterioration that a bad handling will create. It seems that they never fail to surprise, this present Chinese administration has gone all out with incompetence and malfeasance.
I should have known better after the actions taken with the concentration camps to jail the Islamic population, hell, they are worse than any forecast I was considering.
As I had expected before it is certain now that this will happen this weekend after latest official number 724 is very close to 774 with the increase in the last day being 90.

As at now the number of deaths is around 730 and will likely become more than the SARS total by the end of today, as there are reported to be over 6,000 patients in a critical condition.  It appears that there are also people who have died who probably had CoV but were not tested for the virus. How many is not known.

724 people have died so far from the Novel Coronavirus (2019-nCoV) outbreak as of February 8, 2020, 12:00 GMT.
https://www.worldometers.info/coronavirus/coronavirus-death-toll/ ~90/day and rate still increasing.

under reported, and four additional provinces reporting one case each...yeah, right, just one. kids can be asymptomatic, current testing doesn't show them as carriers even though they are. NYT today: The death toll and the number of infections continued to climb in China, according to official data released early Friday. Nationwide, more than 70 new deaths and 3,100 new cases emerged in the previous 24 hours, the national health authorities said Friday morning.
The new figures brought the total number of deaths in China to at least 636. And the total number of confirmed cases rose to 31,161. "Sixty-nine of the newly reported deaths occurred in Hubei Province, the heart of the outbreak, the authorities said, but there were also four deaths outside of the province: one each in Jilin, Henan, Guangdong and Hainan Provinces." nyt "Corona with those fries, sir?"

The death toll, as reported by the BNO Newsdesk ( https://twitter.com/BNODesk ) is now 719. That's an additional 84 deaths since the last BNO report, and 55 short of the SARS total. The next WHO report, with deaths through the end of today, will accordingly be a bit short.  The one after that, with the deaths through February 8th listed, will report more than the 774 killed by SARS, since there is no way that the number of daily deaths is going to suddenly crater.

Currently (Feb 7) the death toll sits at 638, 137 fatalities away from exceeding the SARS outbreak. Over the past week, an average of 60 fatalities occurred daily (though in the past week this number has been over 70). This is likely an underestimate of the fatality rate since the rate has been increasing daily. If this trend continues, a conservative estimate of 60 fatalities a day would put the Wuhan coronavirus exceeding the SARS outbreak by Feb 10. This is days and days before the first deadline of Feb 15, so even if there was some sort of black swan event, the Wuhan coronavirus would still beat SARS in this given time.
Will happen the day after tomorrow.
NYT:  new figures brought total number of deaths in China to at least 636. Total number of confirmed cases rose to 31,161.

SARA killed about 774 people of 8096 infected, a death rate of between9 to 10%. The death rate for 2019 c-Cov is about 2.1% (maybe 3%). Currently about 40,000 are listed to be infected.  A compute model forecasts (I read) a final Wuhan of "...up to..." 75,815.  Rounding up to 80,000 for all of China (too low perhaps) and using 2.1per cent death rate = 1600.  As of 2/6 dead are 636 in China and rising fast.   Doubling est 6 to 7 days.  Feb 7 + 7 days = Feb 14, so 2 x 636 = 1272 by Feb 14.  Model indicates passing Sars 774 probably by Feb 10.

Only 10K to go:

We are on pace to exceed 774 in about 2 days.  I'm ready to go 100%.

And today's death total report is 635, per the latest BNO report ( https://twitter.com/BNODesk ) and 70 new daily deaths (one happened after the usual midnight summary). The average number of deaths/day over the last seven days is accordingly up to 60 (from 56.1 yesterday). We are now 139 deaths from exceeding the SARS death total, with 9 days to go. It's the next thing to absolutely certain. Best estimate of the date the SARS total will be exceeded remains February 8th (since the last couple of days have been 70+), with February 9th as an outside possibility.
Shifting my forecast now that we are at Feb 6 with more than 560 deaths.

The death toll from the new coronavirus has exceeded that of the severe acute respiratory syndrome outbreak in 2002 and 2003 in mainland China as 349. WHO reported on Feb 2020 that there were 24363 confirmed (3893 new), 3219 severe (431 new), 491 deaths (66new) nationwide. During the SARS outbreak, 349 people died in mainland China. 
https://www.nytimes.com/2020/02/03/world/asia/coronavirus-china.html
https://www.who.int/docs/default-source/coronaviruse/situation-reports/20200205-sitrep-16-ncov.pdf?sfvrsn=23af287f_4

So far, about 2/3 of the people that have died from the virus is over the age of 60. But the whistleblower doctor, who appears young and healthy from this picture, died on Feb 1 after being hospitalized on Jan 12. So assuming a 2 week incubation period and then add 3 weeks from hospitalization to death, that's about 5 weeks. The outbreak news has only become big news in the last week or two. And most of the people that died sooner were older and weaker. I think the death numbers could rise dramatically in the upcoming weeks. (For people saying that this virus is not worse than the common flu, is it normal to quarantine 60 million people for the common flu? I think we're dealing with something much worse.)

The contagion rate has gone down as expected in an S curve, the fatality rate has held steady at 2% but I expect it to go down as new hospitals in the area start operating.

2.  Global ramp-up of mitigation measures.

Even if the virus doesn't break out in a significant way from Wuhan, the current 2000-4000 increase in infections will result in deaths surpassing SARS by 15 Feb.  That being said, a slight decrease in infection rate will move the date beyond 15 Feb.
We have 8 days until the first deadline, and we are on pace to top 774 in about 3 days.

My best estimate has remained steady at around Feb 8th for the last few days.
Infection and death rate have been pretty linear in past week.  At current rate of ~40 deaths/day will surpass SARS in 7-9 days.

Contagion has held steady around 19% daily increase, reported death rate has gone down slightly, but that has other variables that can lead to under-reporting.  There would need to be a major change in the contagion trend so as not to surpass SARS deaths before February 15th.

The current trend of ~2000 new victims per day suggests the number of infected persons could reach 38,750 by 13 Feb, but a slight reduction will push it past 15 Feb.

Dateline 2-4-2020 -- The official Chinese death toll from the coronavirus outbreak now stands at 361, overtaking the number during the SARS outbreak when 349 people died on the Chinese mainland. However, the coronavirus does not seem to have the same fatality rate as SARS, and the recovery rate also seems to be improving. -- from Foreign Policy Morning Brief newsletter.

The rate of increase has declined but the trend line suggests the SARS figure will be passed around the 8th Feb.  However there is some reason to question the accuracy of the figures going forward. China appears to be reporting its figures, but Thailand is maybe slower to report. It has reported 6 new cases today which seems to be an increase of around 30% in a day (I am not sure if some of these have been double counted). There are reports that people in other countries, who have not been to China, have been infected during visits to Thailand. They could have just been very unlucky or it could be that there are a lot more infected people in Thailand (than officially counted) to pass the virus on.  It could be that Thailand is at the stage that China was around the 12th Jan just before the number of case took off.  The time between supposed dates of becoming infected, dates when the infection has been diagnosed, and indeed deaths does show the problem in controlling the outbreak.  The deaths seem to occur a week or more after the diagnosis, which is up to 2 weeks after the infection.

-Latest WHO Situation Report* states that there have been a total of 362 deaths so far, of which 57 are new.
-Latest SCMP update* (more recent than WHO Sit Rep, incorporating most recent Chinese Gov data release) states that there have been a total of 426 deaths so far, of which 64 are new since the last WHO Situation Report.
*All cited links are in my sheets Latest modeling based on the percent growth rate so far (of which there are four models: 1) based on last day's percent growth; 2) based on 1/2 of last day's percent growth, 3) based on average of last 3 days percent growth, 4) based on 1/2 of average of last 3 days percent growth): https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1RU4wiWov1YtjAhTOB_sq9uRBJIP6OmN6dsLOQrWEGd4/edit?usp=sharing
-Under the better case scenario of a daily growth rate of 9.3% from now until Feb. 15, there will be about 1k confirmed deaths by Feb. 15. Under this model, the 774 death figure will be surpassed on Feb. 12. 
-Under the worse case scenario of a daily growth rate of 19.3% from now until Feb. 15, there will be about 3k confirmed deaths by Feb. 15. Under this model, the 774 death figure will be surpassed on Feb. 9.

So, today's death total report is 426, per the latest BNO report ( https://twitter.com/BNODesk ), which means there have been 64 new deaths.  The average number of deaths/day over the last seven days is accordingly up to 45.6 (from 40.1 yesterday). With 426 deaths, we are 348 deaths from exceeding the SARS death total, with 12 days to go.  So unless something cuts the average death rate to 29/day going forward, we will exceed the SARS death total. And the fact is, we're still seeing increases in the daily rates of new deaths, severe cases, and known cases, rather than a leveling-off, much less a decline.

However data contradicts this and % have to be adjusted accordingly. Check out https://www.worldometers.info/coronavirus/coronavirus-death-toll/ and https://www.worldometers.info/coronavirus/ (note that the scale is logarithmic, so that apparently linear trend would look exponential on a linear scale). @jayb is right in his logic a few comments below. At the same time, if there's a massive difference in between the actual people having nCOV2019 and the reported number of case, there's also going to be a massive difference in between who do we know died of it, thus who WHO knows died of it and that only by 15th of Feb... The trend is clear. It's not SARS, not MERS and it's spreading a LOT faster then those did. It already reached a pandemic level. Mortality is low but even 1% from 1.000.000 = 10.000, without the possibility of vaccinating from it so... it's not exactly good news. Even in the very-less-likely scenario that the death toll would, for some reason, stay at a steady rate of ~40 deaths confirmed per day, it would still go over 774 by 15th of Feb. Right now, death rate is growing constantly for over 1 week and it shows no sign to stop, nor it has any reason to since the number of confirmed cases is also growing constantly. There is a chance WHO won't get a lot more reports by 15th of Feb, there's also a chance trying new cocktails of meds might have some positive results. Still, most importantly, there simply can't be more people in the hospital at the same time diagnosed by medics so... we can't say who has it, who doesn't and who dies by it in China alone. That being said, a reasonable amount of 30% has to be attributed to post 15th of Feb as things look right now. *Subject to reconsider based on future data*

(As noted below,) The number of new confirmed cases being reported has been growing significantly over the last few days. (https://www.reuters.com/article/us-china-health/china-virus-toll-rises-as-chinese-markets-set-to-reopen-after-holiday-idUSKBN1ZX00T) 
Even if that variable - somehow - lowers to 2000 new cases/day, that could hypothetically still add over 20,000 new cases by February 14. Using an early-outbreak, largely-estimated mortality rate of 2% (https://www.worldometers.info/coronavirus/coronavirus-death-rate), that could still mean an additional 440 deaths (or so), also by February 14. Via this very simple example the total SARS death toll (774) would be exceeded (361 already-reported deaths plus 440 possible new deaths), by (end of) Feb. 14. FWIW, two potential - perhaps slight - mitigating factors: The chance that existing coronavirus cases are actually vastly under-reported (thus far), possibly indicating a significantly lower actual mortality rate (for the virus)(https://www.sciencealert.com/new-study-estimates-75-000-people-in-wuhan-infected-with-coronavirus). 
And, a report that Thai doctors have been able to improve (not cure) the condition of a small number of seriously ill coronavirus patients with an early (not-yet-widely tested/implemented) 'cocktail' of presently-available medicines (https://news.yahoo.com/cocktail-flu-hiv-drugs-appears-124753996.html).

Updated according to the logic of my previous prediction: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/961751

Data for Wuhan coronavirus infection and fatality cases are obtained from Wikipedia [1].  The data have been updated everyday.  Since mid-January, the number of confirmed cases has been rising exponentially.  In the last 7 days (since 26 January), its rise is almost a straight line.  A linear regression of the 7-day data shows a slope of 1898 cases per day.  Closer examination of the data indicates that the rate of increase is getting faster, e.g. 2099 in 31 January and 2579 in 1 February.   This rapid rise in infected cases is reminiscent of the SARS.  At the height of the SARS outbreak, the number of infected cases increased rapidly for 2 weeks before tapering off [2].  However in the Wuhan case, the rapid rise has just started.  It is reasonable to expect this rapid rise will continue for at least another two weeks (remember that the rise rate is actually increasing). During this 7-day rising period, the fatality rate for the Wuhan outbreak is slightly higher than 2% (2.3% to be more exactly).   If we assume the linear regression slope (a conservative estimate since the infection rate appears to be increasing) and a 2.3% fatality rate, the number of infected cases will be 38483 by 14 February and total death will be 885 which is higher than the total SARS deaths of 774.  I am forecasting 90% for before 15 February and 10% between 15 February and 31 March right now.  If the infection rate continues to rise in the next few days, I will increase the probability in the first bucket. [1] 
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_the_2019%E2%80%9320_Wuhan_coronavirus_outbreak
[2] https://www.who.int/csr/sars/country/en/

We already have at least 200 dead people in China. So past 25% mark.
Coronavirus is different from SARS. It has a lower fatality (around 1-2%) compared to SARS. But it spreads faster, as you infect the virus before even symptoms appear. So fatality number of this question depends on the overall of people who caught coronavirus. 
So the question is how fast we would have 75k people infected. Not in two weeks, but probably in two months.

First update, an a counterintuive one by the way because contrary to most forecasters, I am reducing the probability for the first bucket. The first thing is that there is signs of a transition from exponential to linear. It is not clear whether this is because the quarantine is actually working, or because of a series of other external factors distorting the real numbers (lack of test kits, intentional underreporting, necessity to demonstrate the narrative that the quarantine is working). Be it as it may, it will be really unlikely that the numbers of the WHO would contradict the Chinese numbers for the time being, even if they suspect that they might be doctored or might contain methodological errors. Right now I will consider three scenarios: 1) Linear growth from today till February 14th in China (which will correspond to the WHO data of February 15th): this gives something of the order of 900 death with a standard deviation of 100 2) Saturation: I fit the cases and numbers of deaths to a model of the type  Cases(n) = HC * (1 + Tanh((n - n0)/lambda) Here HC is half-the-total projected cases, n is the number of days (n=18 is Feb 2, n=19 Feb 3, etc), n0 the offset, and lambda a time scale. For deaths I get HC = 293, n0 = 17.3, lambda = 6.3, while for cases it is a similar number but with HC = 10791. The statistical error in HC seems to be small, which means saturation at about 600 deaths and an almost zero probability of reaching SARS before February 15th. 3) Exponential growth, in which case we reach the number of cases before Feb 15. Model 1) gives about 80-90% probability of reaching the number before Feb 15, 2) gives a 0% because this will never reach the number of cases of SARS, at last if there is not a second outbreak and 3) gives about 100%. By averaging the three I get 60-63% for the first bucket. Now this have to be revised in about four hours when the new data from China are updated. Saturation predicts that we will move from 304 to 350 cases. If tonight we have 350 cases I will begin to believe the saturation hypothesis. Otherwise, I will re-update. Update: 360 deaths, a bit above what expected in the saturation model. Refitting gives HC = 323, and saturation about 646 deaths. Probably there is something right in the saturation model for the current situation, but it underfits the trend. I will reduce it's likelihood by half, let's say, will will leave me with 72-76% for the first bucket.

What is clear is that we've already reached a high number of infected and there will be some growth over the next couple of weeks, even if the epidemic can be brought under control.

When will fatalities caused by the Wuhan coronavirus (2019-nCoV) exceed those from Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS), according to the World Health Organization (WHO)? Jan 30 WHO reports 178 fatalities in 7818 cases roughly one month after disease was noticed. At a constant rate, 35K cases would be required to exceed SARS, which is roughly 4-5 times today's known cases. It would appear that the number of cases would be reached by 15 Feb, but assume better care of those infected would reduce fatalities.

One more comment: The question asks about WHO reporting. Currently the WHO is publishing updates daily and I'll assume that will continue. However their reports seem to generally lag the news reports by about a day. I assume they are more conservative in their methodology and perhaps also have an approval process that delays publications. The net result is that I need to add 1-2 days to my estimate.

Based on yesterday's (1/30) data, it appears that relative to my model: 
1) Rate of growth of suspected cases was lower than expected (by me) yesterday. Is exponential growth rate slowing?. ~25% yesterday vs ~50%/day for the prior week. This has also translated to slowing in the growth of confirmed cases. ~25% yesterday vs ~45-50% for the prior week. I'm going to assume that the rate of exponential growth will continue to decline sharply. Modeling 25% for a few more days and then 20%. 
2) Severity dropping slightly: 11% severe / confirmed (vs 13% prior week). Also death rate (current deaths / current severe cases, which is different than a typical definition of death rate) stable or down a bit a 2.5-3%. I'm assuming 2% going forward.  With the above assumptions I get the expected day we exceed SARS cases to be Feb 9th.  @Greyowlsova makes an interesting point about mass testing leading to non-trivial numbers of false positives. Can you put a number on that?
What a turn around! This virus has spread more aggressively than predicted and has higher percentage of fatality. Too bad that I have to upgrade my analysis in just a day.

The Wuhan coronavirus has reached over 200 deaths in about one month; SARS killed 774 over 9 months. Chinese hospitals are facing severe resource shortages which is significantly increasing the possibility that those who need treatment will not receive it (NYT),  additionally the fact that so little is known about the virus at this point leaves the possibility for dangerous mutations beyond the current known rates of transmission (Foreign Policy). Despite the strong response China has taken in quarantining Wuhan, it is likely that the damage has already been done to the residents of Wuhan and an approaching increase in deaths due to lack of treatment and continued transmission in overloaded hospitals is inevitable.

(1/30/20): Conservatively, using just (an estimated) 70% of the rate of increase of global confirmed cases seen over the past three days (per WHO reports, incl. https://www.who.int/docs/default-source/coronaviruse/situation-reports/20200130-sitrep-10-ncov.pdf?sfvrsn=d0b2e480_2) : 1795 new cases (WHO report of 1/28/20) + 1472 new cases (1/29) + 1753 new cases (1/30) multiplied by .7 (est) = 3514 divided by 3 = (conservatively) an average of about 1,171 new cases per day, possibly for at least the short term future.  If this is an accurate rough estimate (holding some other factors), we could have over 8000 new cases a week from today. (2/6/20). Mortality estimates for Coronavirus remain sketchy, but roughly two to 4% has been suggested. (See my previous forecasts for sources if interested.) 8000 multiplied by an estimated 2.5% fatality rate would indicate possibly 200 additional deaths from the virus a week from today. That would (unfortunately) put the overall toll (incl. current reports) at about 370 deaths in a week, almost halfway to the final toll of SARS. Particularly adjusting the "15 February to 31 March" question option upward some, mainly on a bit of personal optimism that various countermeasures may at least somewhat slow virus spread + death toll. Will verify via future WHO reports. Also considered (article link): https://time.com/5773735/coronavirus-outbreak-trajectory/

It appears to me to be a hard mathematical fact that we're seeing exponential growth in officially reported confirmed cases, suspected cases and deaths. The rate of exponential growth may be starting to slow, but still exponential.  There are two hypotheses that could explain the appearance of exponential growth in official figures through 1/29: 
1) The disease is still in it's exponential growth phase.  2) Alternatively, as pointed out by @JC4841 and @Greyowlsova (and implied by others in their estimates) the appearance of exponential growth in official figures may instead be reflective of things like increasing awareness/education of clinicians, the rate at which the government response is ramping up, the capacity of laboratory diagnostics ramping up, etc. These other growth rates may themselves be exponential in nature for a while and have nothing to do with the underlying growth of the disease.  I believe that both are true to an extent, but that the numbers mostly reflect the progress of the disease. In other words I think hypothesis 1 is "more true" than #2 and is the right one to use for modeling.  If the first is true then the questions is: when and by how much will the exponential growth slow and eventually peak? If the second is true then the question is: what's the true underlying rate of growth of the disease?  How can we test to determine which hypothesis is more likely? (That's not a rhetorical question; I really don't know.)  Observations: 
1) The official confirmed figures are minimum numbers so are clearly "wrong" in the sense that they are incomplete/too low, perhaps by a lot, because they only include cases confirmed with a laboratory test. Presumably some (many?) people have the virus and have not been tested.  2) Office figures appear to be internally inconsistent because the implied relationship between R0, case growth rate and incubation time doesn't make sense in terms of standard epidemiological models. See: https://www.newscientist.com/article/2231864-new-coronavirus-looks-set-to-cause-a-pandemic-how-do-we-control-it/ From what I gather, the most likely explains are some combination of:
    -- there are many more cases that currently reported and these are mostly milder cases
    -- incubation time is shorter that currently thought
    -- R0 is lower than implied by the data

3) It's almost certainly true that the ramp-up in government testing capabilities and outreach efforts is partly responsible for the increase in reported cases. 4) In general governments have an incentive to downplay the severity of epidemics. I'm not implying that anyone in the US or China is doing that, but maybe in other countries that could be an issue. For example I can imagine countries like Thailand not wanting to scare away tourists in peak season. My current estimate is that we'll hit >800 cases around Feb 12-14. I assume a drastic slow-down in the rate of growth, the percent of severe cases and the death rate.

IMHO, people behave as if SARS never happened. During SARS outbreak (and afterwards) quite robust international system was put in place to prevent things like that. The Chinese government also learned a lesson and you can see now how they vigorously installed emergency measures. Most probably, fast increasing numbers now reflect to quite significant extent better diagnostics of prior cases rather than epidemics out of control. With better diagnostics, comes better treatment and less fatalities. I believe we'll see significant slowdown of fatalities (and overall infections) within a month after medical establishment catches up.
Quick edit to my original forecast, making numbers slightly less conservative

80 deaths from 1/8/2020 to 1/27/2020 (4/day). An additional 90 deaths were announced 1/28 and 1/29. 2.2% of cases have resulted in death (170 of 7711). I'm tempted to pick a more conservative (i.e. slow) estimate. However I'd rather err on the aggressive side and then back it off tomorrow if the data comes in showing a slowdown in the rate.

I am using similar logic to @Dillyweed. I am assuming a doubling of the total deaths every 3 days (25% increase per day) so over 17 days. Are we working to China Standard Time or UTC? If UTC it seems there were 130 at 00:00 29/01/2020, so that suggests 260 by 00:00 01/02/2020, 1040 by 00;00 07/02/2020, 2080 by 10/02/2020 and 4160 by 13/02/20 and so 6500 before 15th Feb.    There were 774 SARS deaths according to the WHO, so if current rate of 2019-nCOV continues the SARS figure would be passed by about 4th Feb.  A 25% increase per day is only approximate so there is clearly a chance that it slows down, but it could speed up. As it is thought that it could take two weeks for infected people to show symptoms, and the measures China has introduced to slow down the risk of it spreading were only introduced a few days ago, it is reasonable to suppose that the number of people who are infected, but don't yet know it, has increased considerably and any affect from the measures taken will not start to affect the number of known cases for at least another 10 days, and the death rate increase would not be affected for about another two weeks.   It has been suggested by other forecasters that regimes to treat there viruses have improved since SARS. I don't know how true this is, but the fact is the rates of deaths are what they are, so presumable this takes account of improved treatments as well as this virus spreading more efficiently.   So unfortunately I think its almost certain that the SARS figure will be reach before 15th Feb,

(1/29/20:) 32% increase in globally confirmed cases reported in one day, 1/28/20 to 1/29/20. (Source: https://www.who.int/emergencies/diseases/novel-coronavirus-2019/situation-reports/) Expected Coronavirus mortality rate is not fully known, but I've seen estimates of two to four percent. (https://www.who.int/docs/default-source/coronaviruse/situation-reports/20200123-sitrep-3-2019-ncov.pdf, https://www.washingtonpost.com/health/coronavirus-spread-containment-strategy/2020/01/28/84c25030-4200-11ea-aa6a-083d01b3ed18_story.html) A very simplistic, perhaps conservative calculation, using (just) half of the recent 32% daily confirmed cases increase (ref. above) and a 3% expected mortality rate: 
1/29/20 6065 confirmed cases X 1.16 = a possible increase of about 970 cases per day. Using that (conservative?) rate, there may be 6790 new confirmed cases seven days from today. Carrying this example further: 6065 cases (as of 1/29/20) + 6790 new, projected cases = 12,855 worldwide cases (possibly) by 2/5/20. 12,855 X .03 projected mortality rate = approx. 386 possible deaths by 2/5/20, 132 of which have already occurred per WHO reporting. (I.e., conservatively projecting (roughly) a 254 death increase in seven days.) I believe my simplistic example above may be conservative (about new cases), unless outbreak countermeasures currently underway prove generally effective. Adjusting initial forecast only a little downward pending WHO reporting over the next few days.

Revising my forecast. The numbers below put my expectation right around Feb 15th. If I do my calculation another way, by simply observing the exponential growth of reported deaths, I get an estimate of around Feb 6th when we exceed 800. If the growth rate starts to show signs of dropping below exponential in the coming days (which seems likely) then I'll need to revise that forecast.

Currently there are roughly 6k confirmed (with lab analysis) cases which presumably represents the majority of the serious cases. There are an additional 9k suspected cases and 60k people in quarantine. The number of confirmed cases has been following a steady exponential growth through yesterday (1/28 in china) and has been roughly doubling every 2 days. In all probability we have already had more cases than from the entire SARS epidemic. The death rate based only on the number of confirmed cases has been reported as roughly 2.5%. This is indeed the number you get when you divide deaths by number of confirmed cases. However I believe this represents a conservative estimate and the true number is higher because some of the confirmed cases will ultimately die. Considering that over the 1/4 of the confirmed cases weren't known 4 days ago and it takes roughly 4 days from onset of serious symptoms to death (need to confirm this), then I assume this number could be up to 4x higher or 10%. This is presumably too high. I'm using 5% in my calculations.  To reach 774 deaths at 5%, there would need to be ~15k cases. At 2.5% that would be 30k. We should be there in about 3 days for 15k or about 4-5 days for 30k (assuming exponential growth continues).  It will take another 5-10 days for people to die.  There will be no vaccine in this timeframe, although treating the symptoms better to prevent death and reduce the death rate seems likely assuming the health system isn't overwhelmed.

The death rate has grown at a steady 30% per day, and the chances of underreporting are non-negligible. However, coronavirus treatments have improved considerably since SARS, and this disease seems much less lethal than that. It is not unrealistic to expect governments to converge on a strong treatment regimen before too long.

Fears over the Wuhan coronavirus are severely overblown IMHO. The fatality rate for it are significantly less than for SARS. The basic reproduction rate (the average number of people infected by one infected person), it looks, is also less. The Chinese government (not to mention other countries including the US) is much more prepared than with SARS too. I am not sure that I'd call my forecast a contrarian view, but it is clearly against the crowd as it stands with 5% for May 16 bucket at this point.

If nothing changes, at the simple rate calculated above (if accurate), 106 deaths could potentially become over 1,800 deaths in just another week's time. ...4537 confirmed cases in China as of 1/28/20 (ref. source listed earlier) multiplied by .04 = approx. 182 potential fatalities  -- just from the current number of confirmed (China) cases... 106 of which (via WHO reporting) have already occurred. Unfortunately, right now it is more probable than not that the number of death will go above that one of the SARS in a very short time. Right now we have had an exponential increase in the number of cases (and the number of deaths), which is expected to last at least till about ten days after the quarantine of Wuhan began (leaving at least 4 more days of exponential growth). Now, from a quick look at past week, every six days the number of cases have increased 10-fold. There are about 4 days till the quarantine begins to take full effect and by then we should expect from 10-20 thousand cases, and 300-600 deaths. After that there are still 13 days till the first bucket of the question arrives and in the transition between exponential growth and eventual saturation it could be easier to surpass the SARS mark than not. However this is a very quick and dirty estimation. There's the rest of China, where the tight measures have been taken in the last few days, but a bit later than in Wuhan and Hubei. But this just increases the probability of reaching the mark.
Wuhan cases alone doubling every ~38 hours, deaths even faster. Likely to accelerate when deaths begin in other countries.

- The 2003 epidemic of SARS-Cov resulted in more than 8,000 cases, affected 26 countries, and killed 774 people (WHO data). Since 2004, only a small number of cases have occurred as a result of laboratory accidents or, possibly, through animal-to-human transmission (Guangdong, China).
https://www.cdc.gov/sars/index.html
https://www.cnbc.com/2020/01/28/coronavirus-vs-sars-health-experts-on-the-key-differences.html - Chinese health authorities confirmed that, as of today, the 2019 coronavirus outbreak had infected 4,515 people, with 106 reported deaths. (This means the virus has killed just over 2% of those who have been infected.
Other assessments suggested fatality is 3-4%.
https://www.cnbc.com/2020/01/28/coronavirus-vs-sars-health-experts-on-the-key-differences.html.) - Most reports seem to agree it is still too early to tell how contagious and how lethal the 2019-nCov is. -The WHO said that it is optimistic the Chinese government will contain the virus. At the same time, researchers at Hong Kong University contradicted the WHO, assessing that the 2019-nCov could reach 150,000 infections DAILY at its peak. They used an assessment of infections doubling every 6.2 days for the 2019-nCov. There are indicators that the virus might not be as lethal and that there may be a lot more people with the virus than reported (those reported are for people tested and confirmed) but that many cases may be milder and have not raised the alarm.  From what we've been told so far, there's reason to believe 2019-nCov may be more contagious but less lethal than SARS Cov. The age of social media spreads information and misinformation, panic and conspiracy theories exponentially faster than SARS in 2003. But this might also help people avoid getting the virus and also acting faster at onset of symptoms. Going with WHO and CDC cautious assessment for now.

Roughly, we have 100 fatalities in a time of 4-6 weeks. Projecting that if the total number goes above 774 that will take approximately 5-6 months from beginning of February. i.e. July. Now, this is very rough estimate and there are arguments on both sides.
On good side,
1. China has taken actions that are far more advanced and far early than 2003 SARS outbreak. 
2. Their efforts are more wide as they have locked down 9+ cities within a month.
3. Nearby countries are too taking harder actions. Look at Hong Kong's efforts...etc.
4. They are building extra hospital within compounds of affected cities. This something new that will help containment. On other side,
1. China is still hiding some part of outbreak.
2. China's effort may be little late considering about half (5 MM out of 11 MM) of population of Wuhan have traveled out in anticipation of lock down.
3. Continuing to #2, there are more people traveling nowadays than that of 17 years ago so spreading is quick. You can travel 17 times around the world in 17 days :(
4. If citizens of other countries affected in a disproportional manner, the containment effort by only China may not bring required results.

Over 100 as of right now and increase is much faster than linear. Improved reporting as more test kits for 2019-nCoV are produced is likely to be a factor in an even higher rate of increase on reported deaths. A major factor is that this new disease is much more transmissible than SARS. In the case of SARS, many of the deaths were caused by superspreaders, rare individuals who were far more infective than most victims. But in the case of 2019-nCoV,   Another factor is that health care workers are even more at risk than with SARS . See https://www.cnn.com/2020/01/24/opinions/wuhan-coronavirus-china-strategy-garrett/index.html for some details.
